description: An open-air flea market that serves as a living museum of Georgian and Soviet history, located on the Dry Bridge (Mshrali Khidi) and adjacent Dedaena and 9 March parks. Known as 'the market of memories,' this beloved attraction has been connecting locals and visitors with Georgia's past since the 1950s, offering everything from Soviet-era memorabilia to handmade Georgian crafts.
highlights: Extensive collection of Soviet-era kitsch and USSR memorabilia including war medals, ID books, photographs, and items featuring Stalin and Lenin
Antiques and collectibles: porcelain, vintage jewelry, old Georgian and Soviet books, coins, maps, and vinyl records
Handmade Georgian crafts: feltwork, crochet items, khinkali and khachapuri felt toys, kantsi drinking horns, and panduri instruments
Original artwork and paintings by local artists
Vintage cameras, caviar tins, enamel engravings, silver jewelry, ornate swords, and radio sets
Split personality market: Soviet memorabilia on one side, handmade crafts and souvenirs on the other
Rich cultural experience with multilingual atmosphere (Georgian, Russian, and some English)
tips: Open daily 10:00 AM to 5:00 PM except major holidays (January 1 and Orthodox Easter Sunday)
Best time to visit: weekends from 11am onwards for most variety, though weekdays offer a more relaxed atmosphere
Arrive early in the day for first pick of items and to avoid afternoon crowds
Bring cash in small Georgian Lari denominations - vendors don't accept cards
Bargaining is expected and part of the experience - be friendly and respectful when negotiating
Prices may be inflated for tourists, especially for Soviet-era items - don't be afraid to haggle
Not everything is genuinely old - some items are Chinese imitations, so buy for fun rather than serious collecting
Inquire about provenance if you're a serious collector
Plan to spend several hours exploring - there's a lot to see
Engage with vendors who are often eager to share stories and history behind their items
Weather-dependent: outdoor market may close during heavy rain or snow
Russian is spoken more than Georgian among older vendors, English less common
vibe: A nostalgic treasure hunt through Georgia's past, where history meets creativity in a lively, authentic atmosphere. The chatter of vendors and bargaining customers reflects Georgian warmth and hospitality, creating an immersive cultural experience that feels like stepping into a living museum. It's a place where desperation turned into community, where personal memories became shared heritage, and where the Soviet past is preserved not in sterile displays but in the hands of locals who lived through it.
expectations: A typical outdoor flea market with standard antiques and souvenirs
Everything being authentically old and valuable
Easy to navigate in an hour or less
reality: A sprawling open-air museum spanning multiple parks with genuine historical significance
Relaxed vendors with no pressure to buy - window shopping is perfectly acceptable
A mix of authentic Soviet memorabilia, genuine antiques, handmade crafts, and some modern reproductions
A beloved local institution where Georgians come to browse their own history and culture
You can easily spend 3-4 hours exploring and discovering unique treasures
unique_facts: The bridge got its name in the 1940s after the Mtkvari River branch beneath it was redirected - it literally became a 'dry bridge' over a street instead of water
The bridge itself was built between 1847 and 1851, and the river branch was drained in 1933 to protect Old Tbilisi from chronic flooding
The market emerged out of desperation during Perestroika and early independence years when locals sold their personal possessions to make ends meet
It's been one of Tbilisi's most beloved attractions since the 1950s when locals first began bringing their old items to sell
Known as 'the market of memories' because many early vendors were selling their own personal goods and family heirlooms
The market has a fascinating dual personality: Soviet nostalgia on one side, contemporary Georgian handicrafts on the other
Russian is actually spoken more than Georgian at the market, especially among older vendors who grew up during Soviet times
